thread.title_full: LSU basketball signee reportedly talks with NCAA about new book that alleges Louisville used sexual favors in recruiting | NOLA.com

author: Ron Higgins, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune
title: basketball signee reportedly talks with NCAA about new book that alleges Louisville used sexual favors in recruiting
text:
Louisville's 2013 national basketball championship might be in jeopardy if allegations are true in a new book that claims former staff paid escorts to dance for and have sex with players and recruits.
Yahoo Sports obtained a copy Friday of the book titled "Breaking Cardinal Rules: Basketball and the Escort Queen." The book is written by Louisville resident Katina Powell, a self-described madam who allegedly provided women to the Louisville team. Indianapolis-based journalist Dick Cady is a co-author.
SI.com also reported about the book, and said the NCAA was notified of the allegations nearly a month ago, Since then, the NCAA has contacted multiple former Louisville recruits, including LSU freshman signee and former Louisville verbal commitment Antonio Blakeney who the NCAA has recently spoken with. LSU athletic director Joe Alleva declined comment when reached on Friday: "I'm not saying a word," Alleva said.
Powell said Andre McGee, a former Louisville player, was the point man that paid her for her staff's services. He was a graduate assistant under Rick Pitino from 2010-12 and director of basketball operations from 2012-14. He spent last year as an assistant coach at Missouri-Kansas City, working under former Pitino assistant Kareem Richardson.
The book alleges at the peak of the dormitory and off-campus entertainment more than $10,000 cash changed hands to Katina for supplying the women. This doesn't include the hundreds of $1 bills thrown at the dancers at each party by McGee, the recruits and players. Nor does it include the money paid to the women who had sex with the recruits afterward.
The book also alleges that over a four-year period, Powell brought women into the basketball dormitory through a side door to entertain players and recruits. Powell also says her dancers, which included her daughters, also entertained Louisville players at other locations off-campus. After the women danced for the players for an agreed-upon sum, Powell alleges that she would negotiate a second payment for the women to have sex with the athletes.
The book doesn't make any allegation that Louisville head coach Rick Pitino, who survived a sex-related extortion attempt that he announced in 2009, knew of McGee's activities or had knowledge of the women being provided to the players.
